results.title: King of the cats (K)
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: Old Tom the cat stares at his master, the gravedigger, as he tells of an eerie encounter with nine cats mournfully bearing a coffin through the graveyard.

results.title: King of kings
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Ray, Samuel Bronston and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: In a time of violence and fear came a man of peace, hope, love and forgiveness. The man was Jesus and he changed the world. Panoramic scenes of clamorous battles between Roman legions and Judean rebels contrast with the serene faith of Jesus. From his birth in a Bethlehem manger, Christ’s life is brought to the screen with simplicity and eloquence: his forty day ordeal in the desert, selection of the Apostles, the sermon on the Mount, Judas’s betrayal, the Passion and the Resurrection.

results.title: King of diamonds
results.brief_description: Traces the history of diamond mining in South Africa, showing scenes inside diamond mines. Provides an insight into the work required to convert the raw stones into sparkling precious gems.

results.title: King Midas. The Pied piper
results.creator_credit: Edward Bell, Libby Simon and Home Box Office
results.brief_description: Two animated adaptations of fairy tales for children. The Pied Piper (29 mins, 1996): When the town of Hamlyn is overrun with rats, the desperate mayor turns to a mysterious piper who has the power to entice vermin away. But when the selfish King fails to pay for his services, the Piper takes drastic measures. King Midas and the golden touch (27 mins, 1997): A King, who was revelled in a life of wealth and privilege, discovers he has the power to turn all that he touches into gold - but he loses his perspective when he gets caught up in the desire for endless riches. This short film is humorous and quite funky, featuring several groovy musical interludes. Both of these lightly comic fables for children gently moralise about the dangers of avarice, greed, duplicity and selfishness, whilst underscoring the importance of family and tolerance. Features the voices of Samuel L. Jackson, Richard Moll, John Ratzenberger, Grant Shaud, Wesley Snipes, Blair Underwood and Alfonso Ribeiro. Narrated by Robert Guillaume.

results.title: King Lear by William Shakespeare: an introduction
results.creator_credit: Peter Seabourne, John Seabourne and Education Foundation for Visual Arts
results.brief_description: Extracts from Act 1, Scene 1; Act 1, Scene 4; Act 2, Scene 4; Act 5, Scene 3 of Shakespeare’s play ‘King Lear’. In an accompanying handbook Sir Tyrone Guthrie considers the history of the play, Elizabethan theatre, Shakespeare’s company, and the historical background of the period.

results.title: King Lear (Ian Holm)
results.creator_credit: Richard Eyre, Sue Birtwistle, Chestermead and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Ian Holm plays the tragic figure of King Lear who is driven mad by deception and his own foolish egoism. Lear makes a catastrophic decision, ousting the loyal and honest Cordelia, retaining his two remaining deceitful daughters who intend to dethrone him. “King Lear” is a tragedy that repeatedly portrays the restless intolerance of the young towards the old, the powerlessness of virtue in the face of deceit, and the fragility of the bonds which hold families and communities together. In this adaptation, made for television, director Richard Eyre sets the scene with admirable minimalism, allowing for language and gesture to be at the fore of the production, staged by the Royal National Theatre, to great acclaim. A majestic tragedy of misplaced trust and filial ingratitude.

results.title: King Lear
results.creator_credit: Peter Brook, Michael Birkeit, Columbia, Royal Shakespeare Company and Martin Ransohoff Productions
results.brief_description: This Shakespearian tragedy tells the tale of woe when an old king decides to divide his kingdom amongst his daughters. Directed by Peter Brook and starring Paul Scofield and Irene Worth.

results.title: King Lear
results.brief_description: Kozintsev approached the play by creating a total environment for his characters to dwell in - a vast no-man’s land of moor and marsh populated by small communities in primitive castles and clusters of farm dwellings. He has made a superb film which from its beginning portends a tottering natural order and is filled with true Shakespearian energy, a mood doubly enhanced by the splendid score by Shostakovich which lifts the film onto an epic plane. In Russian with English subtitles.
